([[Greenock]], Scotland; 19 November 1972) | Largest win = {{fbw|ENG}} 13 â 0 {{fbw-rt|HUN}}
([[Tapolca]], Hungary; 27 October 2005) | Largest loss = {{fbw|NOR}} 8 â 0 {{fbw-rt|ENG}}
([[Moss, Norway]]; 4 June 2000) | World cup apps = 3 | World cup first = 1995 | World cup best = Quarter-finals, [[FIFA Women's World Cup 1995|1995]], [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2007|2007]], [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2011|2011]] | Regional name = [[UEFA Women's Championship]] | Regional cup apps = 8 | Regional cup first = [[1984 UEFA Women's Championship|1984]] | Regional cup best = Runner-up, [[1984 UEFA Women's Championship|1984]], [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009|2009]] | type=women }} The '''England women's national football team''' represents England in international [[women's football (soccer)|women's football]]. The side has been quite successful of late, qualifying for three [[FIFA Women's World Cup|World Cups]], [[FIFA Women's World Cup 1995|1995]], [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2007|2007]] and [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2011|2011]]. In 2009, the side had their most impressive achievement to date by reaching the [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009|European Championships]] final, losing 6â2 to [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]]. In May 2009 it was announced that a number of the England Women's Team would be awarded central contracts, to help the players concentrate on full-time training and playing, without having to fit it around full-time employment. Seventeen players initially signed contracts.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/WomensSeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/2009/CentralContractsAnnouncement.aspx|work=[[The Football Association|FA]] website|title=Central contracts confirmed|date=14 May 2009}} == Honours == ===Performance in World Cup=== *Unofficial competitions: **1970: 4th **1971: 5th **1978: 1st round **1984: 1st round **1985:
